Ladywolf

To those of you who don't agree that others should be homosexual, would you want a lesbian for a wife?
 
 Would you want that woman to throw up on you everytime you tried to get her to give you head? If you did over power her and had sex with her, wouldn't you get tired of having to hold her down against her will? If she did agree to have sex with you, wouldn't you hate to always have sex in the dark because she can't stand to look at your naked body?
 
 Wouldn't you miss sex as she would eventually not have sex with you? I mean, you can't go outside of marriage because that would be a sin according to your precious bible. You would have to stay with her until death do you part. And what if you wanted children? Not in that marrige would it happen.
 
 And what about everyday life...wouldn't you miss being with someone who would appreciate a man? The wife would never hold you, kiss you, bear your children. She would look at you with resentment and growing hatred for her not being able to be who she truely is?
 
 Why couldn't you just leave things the way they are and live and let live?

Despite the drama in Ladywolf's post, it does bring up a very good point.
 
 One argument against homosexual marriage that I have heard on numerous occasions is that homosexuals aren't denied any rights. That they can marry, too, as long as it's to someone of the opposite sex.
 
 This leaves the gaping question =< How many heterosexuals want to marry someone who is gay, does not romantically love them and is not interested in them to quite possibly repulsed by them sexually?

Why would a straight guy want a women who deosn't really want what they ahve to offer (sexually). It would be boring and unsatisfying. I am sure it happens but why bother?

 
 
 Jitobear and JoeBrummer: I think you are seeing exactly what Ladywolf was trying to suggest. 
 
 Indeed, if gays are already offered the "right to marry" as long as it's someone of the opposite gender, just like everyone else (heterosexuals) how on earth would they actually become married at all, especially to someone of whom they have absolutely no romantic connections? 
 Why would any heterosexual want that either? 
 
 The only thing I can see by forcing gays to continue to only have the "right" to marry those of whom they have no romantic involvement would be an open door for fraud and governmental system abuse. 
 Gay men marrying lesbians and vise versa soley for the benefits of which heterosexuals receive without question. 
 Kind of sounds like citizens of other nations marrying citizens of the U.S. just to gain resident status although they have never actually had any kind of "romantic" relationship. Both are abuses of our system.
 
 In my mind it would only make sence to aviod this kind of fraud by allowing gays to legally marry those of whom they are actually romantically involved. Anything else is a lie and a fraud on tax payors. 
 
 I guess heterosexuals must actually enjoy paying out their tax money to promote and perpetuate fruad. 
 :xbanghead

Okay, yes, I went a little overboard on my example of everyone having the same right to marry (as long as it's with the opposite sex).
 
 I'm going through a medication change and sometimes my thinking goes a little wacky (at least I can laugh at myself about it with dignity). emoticon_rolleyes 
 
 Yes, when I was younger I went along with the "have a find a nice Jewish doctor/lawyer/rich person and settle down". Had some okay experiences (men who treat women with dignity and respect as well as experiences with men that have really intricate dark sides). I'm over it for the most part, it just sneaks out now and then. emoticon_cool 
 
 But you all did get the jist of my post there about being able to marry...just have to marry a man. What man would want to marry a lesbian and what woman would want to marry a gay man? Like Justin said, it brings of thoughts of fraud and abuse and that's not who I am.

Here's my problem with it - it's COMPLETELY implausible and illogical.
 
 Why would anyone be in such a relationship if it was as bad as you paint it? Male or female?
 
 No one is forced to live with or marry another person. You aren't forced to marry or live with a straight man, any more than I would be forced to marry or live with a gay man.
 
 I know what you're trying to get at, but IMHO, it's a pretty weak argument.
 
 Who we enter into a relationship with is purely our choice. 
 
 Whether or not the state recognizes it is a whole other story.
 
 Waxy

 Not quite. The state doesn't force anybody into any relationship. Even in the absence of legitimate homosexual marriage, lesbians are not forced to marry heterosexual men. They, of course, may do so if they choose but if they are physically repulsed by the thought of sexual intercourse with men why would they? 
 
 I suppose you could try to make the argument that they deserve the same privileges as married people and the only way to recieve them is to marry outside their sexual preference. I think this is where you are trying to go with this whole thing. By putting same-sex marriage on the same level of 'marriage-of-conveniece' you are really shooting yourself in the foot.
